item.title: IBM adds new Linux centers
item.description: Big Blue adds several new centers worldwide devoted to Linux specialties in energy, government and mainframes, part of its effort to spread the operating system as widely as possible.

item.title: Macromedia suite half off with new Mac
item.description: In an attempt to boost its share of the Macintosh market, Macromedia cuts in half the price of its Studio MX Web content-creation software suite for people who buy a new Mac.

item.title: Microsoft's plug-and-play biometrics
item.description: The software giant signs a deal with AuthenTec, a maker of fingerprint-recognition sensors, to integrate software support for biometrics into the Windows operating system.

item.title: SuSE gets new telco product, top execs
item.description: The company introduces a new Linux product geared for telecommunications companies, names several new executives and hires an advertising agency to elevate its profile.

item.title: Belgium to tax rewritable CDs
Lexmark preps HP printer salvo
item.description: The printer maker is set to announce new models for its consumer line Tuesday, sources say, as the company tries to nab market share from rival Hewlett-Packard.

item.title: IBM portal takes dictation
item.description: Big Blue introduces a new tool that lets its personalized business portals take dictation from cell phones with a vocabulary of hundreds of thousands of words.

item.title: Microsoft recruits EMC for storage push
item.description: The software giant signs EMC as a partner in its effort to break into storage. The deal gives EMC a chance to compete with Dell and HP in the Windows-based storage market.

item.title: U.K. firm nabs Globalstar majority stake
item.description: A court awards cellular pioneer Craig McCaw's ICO Global Communications a majority stake in the bankrupt U.S. satellite phone provider--as long as it invests $55 million.

item.title: Plumtree to firms: Prune your portals
item.description: The software maker readies a new version of its portal program designed to help businesses avoid what it calls "portal sprawl"--a slew of outdated internal sites.

item.title: W3C updates Amaya browser
Ballmer slipped on Sun and FreeBSD
Napster encourages song theft
Slate's Web magazine first: Making money
item.description:
Slate, the online magazine founded by Michael Kinsley almost seven years ago, took in more money than it spent in the first quarter of this year.
The New York Times

item.title: XM Satellite Radio comes to the PC
item.description: The company makes its 101 channels available to PCs, creating new competition for the recording industry, which is streaming music into millions of homes via the Web.

item.title: Microsoft makes strides on new Windows
item.description: Microsoft has stepped up work on Longhorn, the next version of Windows. A new test version, leaked onto the Web last week, is more advanced than analysts had expected.

item.title: OASIS: Net procurement needs to align
item.description: The Web services standards group launches an effort to create uniform practices for the way companies procure supplies over the Internet.

item.title: Siebel, BEA team up on Web standards
item.description: Siebel Systems and BEA Systems are investing more than $1 million in a joint effort to develop and market e-business standards.

item.title: Cisco shoots for cheaper Net telephony
item.description: The networking company says its forthcoming Internet phones have prices on par with rival products and will spur more offices to use IP telephony.

item.title: Apple unveils music store
item.description: The Mac maker's new digital music service offers downloads for 200,000 songs at 99 cents each, with unlimited CD burning and iPod transfers--among the most liberal licensing terms to date.
